fuelDump.tweet: WELCOME! My name is Tom Scharpling, and this is the NEW home of FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel. It is written LIVE and one sentence at a time.
Starting tonight I will post a chapter from FUEL DUMP every day until we are all caught up. Then I will start writing ALL NEW chapters!
AND HERE IS THE BEGINNING OF THE NOVEL! HERE WE GO!
Tom Scharpling's Twitter Novel, which will be written one sentence at a time....
FUEL DUMP by Tom Scharpling
CHAPTER ONE
Michael Richards stared at the shotgun resting on his coffee table and knew what he had to do.
He picked it up and stared toward the back door, muttering, 'how did it get to this point' over and over.
But he knew how he ended up in this ridiculous position.
And as he flipped up the back hatch of his well-worn Dodge Durango, he knew that the gun in his other hand was the only way out.
The hatch slammed with finality.
Richards looked upwards, toward the belfry that capped the east wing of his Brentwood estate, letting one last "how?" escape his lips.
"Turn left on La Cienega in two hundred feet".
Fucking Garmin.
Can never get that voice selector to stay on the same goddamn setting.
That pimpleface at the Best Buy off of Formosa was full of shit.
But what do I expect at this point?
I go into these stores, they freak out when they recognize me.
Next thing they're forcing me to sign Seinfeld DVDs, jump around, yell at the short guy who works the return counter like he's Mickey.
But in the end, do they ever answer my questions?
No.
They're too busy staring at my pile of hair to pay attention when I'm asking HOW DO YOU KEEP ONE SET VOICE ON THE FUCKING GPS SYSTEM!?
Whatever.
At this point I'm happy they don't call me a racist anymore.
Or at least not as much.
That one guy in the Astro Burger parking lot gave me an earful.
The hardest part is slapping that remorseful look across my face within a heartbeat.
I mean, what do these people want from me?
I fucked up.
Do they think I wanted things to happen like this?
Do they want me to cut my wrists over it?
Because I won't.
I made the mistake, sure.
I carry the burden from that mistake every day.
But if they think I'm going to be a whipping boy for the rest of my life, they've all got another thing coming.
If you kick a dog enough, you can break its will.
But last time I checked, I am not a dog.
I am Michael Fucking Richards.
And I do the kicking around here.
"Make a right turn in point one miles and arrive at your destination, on the left hand side."
A box of ammo jostled on the passenger seat as the Durango drove over a speed bump on DeLongpre Avenue.
Okay, time to do some kicking.
END OF CHAPTER ONE.
The next chapter of FUEL DUMP will be posted tomorrow! Tell everybody about it!
And here comes the next chapter of FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel. Im reposting the past chapters one a day. Then there'll be new chapters!
FUEL DUMP, CHAPTER TWO
"If you play 'Mairzy Doats' one more time I'm going to climb out of this hospital bed and strangle you!"
From behind the dividing curtain, the final strains of the song finished with a flourish.
Then a pronounced CLICK as the cassette deck shut off.
The hospital room was silent for a few long moments until the old man cleared his throat, then spoke in a pronounced Southern accent.
"For yuh information, suh, 'Mairzy Doats' is a part of American history.
The United States government used it during the second World Wah, to relay secret messages".
"I don't give a damn if they played that thing while dropping the bomb- all I want is for YOU to stop playing it, okay?".
The room once again fell silent.
The old man on the other side of the curtain coughed twice, then hit REWIND on his cassette player.
"Oh, fuck this", said the young man as he reached for the call button resting on his lap.
The nurse sitting behind the desk saw the light flash over the doorway of Room 354 for the fifth time that day.
She rose to her feet and waddled towards the room.
"What is it this time, Barry?" she said as she entered.
"The old man won't stop playing his goddamn tape".
"He's not playing it now though".
"Aaaah, he just rewound it.
Trust me, he's getting ready to".
The nurse stepped past Barry's bed and pulled back the dividing curtain.
"Now Mister Beaudreau, are you gonna -"
The nurse stood frozen in her tracks as she saw the old man's face.
He looked deathly.
Sunken.
The cassette player lay ignored across his chest.
"Are you alright, Mister Beaudreau?".
But Randall C. Beaudreau, or 'The Colonel' as they called him, didn't answer the nurse's question.
He licked his lips and muttered, "call my nephew".
"Tell him that his uncle don't have long to live.
Have him get here as soon as possible.
There is something that need him to do for me.
I made a mighty big mess and I need to him fix it."
And that concludes FUEL DUMP for tonight! Tell your friends! Get them on board The Most Exciting Story That Twitter Has Ever Known!
And now the next chapter of FUEL DUMP, my online Twitter novel. One chapter a night, to be followed by new chapters! Tell your friends!
FUEL DUMP, Chapter Two, Part Two.
But flying to Baton Rouge was the last thing on the mind of The Colonel's nephew.
He sat nervously in the waiting room of the midtown office, his leg vibrating a mile a minute.
When would this meeting start?
It's been twenty minutes.
Kurt Beaudreau could feel a cold vertical strip of sweat through his shirt every time he moved, reminding him how badly he needed this.
Finally the secretary looked towards him and caught his eye.
"Mister Beaudreau - he's ready for you now."
The secretary led Kurt down a long hallway toward an office with a very modern frosted glass door.
The man sitting behind the desk looked to Kurt like the character actor Kurt Fuller if he let himself go.
Just thinking about famous Kurts usually helped calm his nerves, but it wasn't working this time.
"Sit down, kid".
Kurt took a seat and shifted uneasily as he waited for the man behind the desk to begin talking.
Finally he leaned forward and spoke, sizing Kurt with his beady eyes the whole time.
"So tell me, what makes you think you're CIGAR AFICIONADO material?"
Kurt was ready for this one.
"Well, sir - I love the magazine first and foremost.
I have always been a student of cigars, from the days when I was a kid watching my father and uncle smoke them down in Louisiana.
They always say that if you can make money at the thing you love, then you have figured out the secret to life.
And if I could get a job writing for CIGAR AFICIONADO magazine, well, I would certainly be doing what l love."
The man behind the desk continued to size up Kurt, running his beady eyes up and down from chest to face and back again.
"That is the biggest crock of horseshit I have ever heard."
The man laughed mockingly as he pulled a Zino Platinum Crown Series Chubby from his desk humidor and rolled a flame over its tip.
The resultant wave of smoke was like a taunting cloud of humiliation, reminding Kurt exactly how far he was over his head.
"This magazine is a piece of shit.
Everybody who works here knows it.
Any writer here worth his salt is doing everything they can to get the fuck out of this dump.
But you look desperate.
Like you really need this job.
Am I right?"
Kurt leaned back, feeling a sick wet squishing as his shirt pressed against his spine.
"You're right - I do need this job, sir.
But I'm not lying about loving cigars.
And I want to write about them.
And if that makes me some kind of joke in your eyes, then I don't know what to say.
But I fell in love with CIGAR AFICIONADO from the first time I saw it.
Pierce Brosnan was on the cover."
The fat man leaned foward and asked, "What was he smoking?"
"It was something Cuban, if I remember correctly.
An El Rey del Mundo.
I recall him preferring its bite with a Pinar del Rio cognac."
"You're serious about this, huh?"
Kurt nodded yes.
"Then I've got something for you.
I want you to write a profile on Kid Rock."
Kurt couldn't believe what he was hearing.
Kid Rock was his Brian Wilson, his Beethoven.
He knew every note of music the man had created.
"I see that look on your face, Kurt.
You're star struck, aren't you."
Kurt couldn't deny it.
But the fat man didn't smile back.
His face turned red as he shouted back his answer, his cigar resting pathetically on the edge of his desk.
"Listen to me and listen good, okay?
Kid Rock is one of the biggest assholes on this planet.
He's not going to make this easy on you.
I want you to get in there and get that interview.
Consider this your audition.
You nail this one, you're good as gold here.
You fuck it up and I'll make sure you never even READ another issue of my magazine."
"I promise you I'll get this interview, sir.
And I will be as good as gold.
Or should I say good as Gold Corona Gorda?"
Kurt waited for the fat man to laugh.
And after a long beat he let out a slight chortle.
"Very funny - now get out of here and get me that interview by next Friday."
Kurt left the office in a whirl of excitement.
He couldn't believe his luck - he would be writing a feature for CIGAR AFICIONADO magazine!
His uncle would be so proud of him.
ut as the kid left through the haze of cigar smoke, the fat man reached for a gray phone from a lower desk drawer and dialed.
"It's Burkett," he said into the receiver.
"I just assigned someone to the Kid Rock thing."
After a pause he answered, "I dunno, some dumb asshole who wrote me a letter saying it was his dream to work here.
He has no idea what he's stepping into."
Burkett sunk back in his chair and exhaled another mist of smoke.
Answering someone on the other end, the fat man laughed before making a prediction.
"I would guess this dumb asshole - Kurt something or other - will be dead by this time next week."
The fat man laughed some more as he pulled another draw from his Zino Platinum Crown Series Chubby.
And that does it for FUEL DUMP tonight! I will repost the next chapter tomorrow! And please spread the word about this!
And here comes another chapter of FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel. Im reposting all the chapters in this new account. SPREAD THE WORD!
FUEL DUMP, CHAPTER THREE.
When Janet Manz took the job as Joe Lieberman's assistant, she assumed she'd be doing some light scheduling, nothing more.
Maybe help him with the grammar on a speech now and again.
But one October night her doorbell rang just as Jay Leno finished up the 'Jaywalk All-Stars' segment, (which always made her laugh).
She tightened her robe and looked through the peephole on her front door.
What she saw shocked her, to say the least.
It was her boss, covered head to toe in blood, muttering under his breath about 'the accident' and 'doing what he had to do'.
She opened the door enough to let the Senator duck inside.
He was even bloodier than he seemed through the door.
His shoes were swimming in the stuff, leaving deep red streaks up and down her carpet.
Leiberman plopped onto her sofa and said to nobody in particular, "Janet, I need three bags of lime and your biggest bottle of bourbon."
After a long shower that drained all her hot water, Leiberman stepped out of Janet's bathroom wearing the robe she got for her birthday.
The robe was at least two sizes too large for him, and a few light streaks of blood ran around the collar.
He was still clearly buzzed from pounding that much alcohol in such a short period.
"Janet, what am I going to do?
I killed a man tonight because I caught him trying to steal something from my briefcase.
Hey, I just noticed that we're both wearing robes... I guess you could call us the Robe Twins, eh?"
Janet didn't laugh at his limp attempt at humor.
"What was he trying to take from you, Senator?"
"Something I've been waiting to get my hands on for a long time.
Something that is going to make me a very very rich man.
If you help me get rid of the body I can cut you in for a chunk of the spoils - how about one third?"
Janet was so far over her head at this point, but she nodded slightly to the senator as she poured the rest of the bourbon into a glass.
Leiberman creaked out a limp smile back before adding, "Great, now let's go get rid of this body in the woods before the sun comes up."
And that does it for FUEL DUMP tonight. Another chapter tomorrow! Remember, after all the existing stuff is posted, the new stuff begins!
It's very flattering to see that @ZinoPlatinum is RTing all mentions of their cigars as written in FUEL DUMP. Here comes ANOTHER CHAPTER!
FUEL DUMP, CHAPTER FOUR.
The Durango rolled into a spot on the street across from the bungalow just as the GPS said, "You have arrived at your destination."
And behind the wheel, Michael Richards was truly starting to freak out.
This isn't just a moment, he realized.
This could be THE moment... the one that changes everything from this point on.
But inside that house was a scumbag who took your hard earned money, he reminded himself.
You didn't put up with Seinfeld's shit for all those years just to have some - don't call him THAT WORD! - "man of color" just steal it.
He turned the rearview mirror, tilting it diagonally so the better part of his face could stare back.
He teased his hair with his left hand, and even though the last few years had been rough he thought he still looked pretty damn good.
He locked eyes with himself.
If this was going to be THE moment after all, he would face it down the way he faced down every other hurdle throughout his life.
The same way he faced down the shouters and critics...the ones who seemed to carry so much more hate in their hearts than he ever held.
"Let's do this," he said to himself as he picked up the gun from the passenger seat.
And a mere thirty seconds later, Michael Richards knocked on the door of the bungalow, a loaded shotgun tapping against his left leg.
Short but sweet, yes? YES. I will repost a chapter a night. When we are caught up, the NEW CHAPTERS WILL START! RT this and spread the word!
And now it's time for tonight's installment of FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel. One chapter a night til we get caught up. Then new chapters!
As he passed the sign reading WELCOME TO CLARKSTON MICHIGAN, Kurt Beaudreau finally allowed himself a quick smile.
He was a few miles away from interviewing Kid Rock for CIGAR AFICIONADO magazine.
His favorite musician, his favorite magazine... he could not believe this fell into his lap.
These are the things that happen to someone else.
Kurt rolled down a gravel road and eventually arrived at the mouth of the Kid Rock compound, tall gates with a regal "KR" on its center.
A box of Maduro Toros rested in his backpack; the perfect 'thank you' gift to a discerning cigar smoker like the former Robert Ritchie.
Kurt pressed the black speaker box alongside the gates and introduced himself.
"Kurt Beaudreau from CIGAR AFICIONADO magazine, here to interview Kid Rock."
A voice answered - Kurt could detect an accent.... maybe a slight hint of something Southern, perhaps from Alabama.
"Kid Rock ain't doing no interviews with no fruity cigar magazine, so why don't you take a seat on your gearshift, okay?"
Kurt stammered for a second, unsure of what to do.
Then he heard the sound of a dirtbike off in the distance, from inside the compound.
It was coming closer.
A splash of gravel coated his car, and through the dustcloud he saw a stringy guy wearing a wifebeater and a porkpie hat.
Kurt tried to mask his nervousness, but HOLY SHIT, THAT IS KID ROCK standing only TEN FEET FROM ME.
The gates opened with a slow certainty and Kid Rock stepped up to Kurt's rental.
"I'm just fucking with you, man!", Kid Rock said, unveiling the self assured sleazy grin that has riveted America for the last decade.
"So pull that piece of shit in here and we'll talk cigars!"
Kurt exhaled deeply, relieved that things like this DO indeed happen to guys like him every once in awhile.
Kid Rock tipped his shades, eying the Sentra as it rolled up his driveway towards the main compound.
"This motherfucker has no idea what he's in store for", he hissed to himself before pulling a long sip off a warm can of Strohs.
And that does it for tonight's portion. More coming tomorrow! And tell your friends! FUEL DUMP!
And now tonight another chapter of FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel, written one sentence at a time.
I am posting all the old chapters on this account, then the new stuff will come!! Tell your friends about it! It's GOOD!
By now The Colonel had grown to accept two things.
One, that this hospital was a godforsaken hellhole with nurses who undoubtedly rifled through your things while you slept.
And two, that his nephew was clearly ignoring his calls.
He pressed the buzzer and summoned the third shift nurse, a pleasant enough lady with an accent from who knows where.
"What is it, Mister Beaudreau?", the nurse asked (with absolutely no accent at all) while hanging in the doorway.
"Muh nephew Kurt - he hasn't called back yet, has he?"
"No, I'm afraid he hasn't".
The Colonel sunk into his bed as best as anyone can actually sink into a hospital bed.
"I need to tell him about the deal I made so so long ago."
The nurse looked at patient Randall Beaudreau, resident of Baton Rouge General Hospital for the last ten weeks with a decided curiosity.
"What kind of deal did you make, Mister Beau - I mean, Colonel?", she asked.
"I hid some money somewhere that nobody would find it... a lot of money."
And just like that, the lives of Randall C. Beaudreau and Nurse Abagail became entangled for the worse.
That's it for tonight. More tomorrow and every night following. We are catching up! The new stuff will melt you!
And here is more FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel being written one sentence at a time. I am posting the past chapters! Then the new ones!
Janet Manz had never seen a dead body before.
She had seen plenty of sick people, sure, but nobody actually deceased.
And she most certainly had never seen a body that had been brutally bludgeoned to death with a Cape Cod Weeder.
But there it was, a heap of flesh and blood and meat, so much wetter than she would've imagined, poured into the Hyundai Genesis trunk.
Senator Leiberman was ten feet away, digging away like a possessed elf on a life-or-death mission.
Janet aimed the flashlight from the Senator to the dead guy in the trunk and back again.
"Janet, hon - do me a favor and try to hold the flashlight still... otherwise I can't see where I'm digging, okay?"
Janet aimed the light back onto Senator Joe, who was standing in a trench that must've been five feet deep by now.
He stopped digging and leaned on his shovel.
The flashlight created the illusion that the thin wisps of hair on his head were made of cotton candy.
"So... can I ask who this guy is?", Janet asked uneasily.
"I would prefer not to tell you at this point, Janet.
Senator Leiberman climbed out of the hole and stuck the shovel into the ground with a firm grunt.
"Now if you wouldn't mind, let's dump this body so we can get out of here before anybody finds us."
Leiberman reached into the trunk without hesitation and picked up one side of the plastic sheet lining the trunk, underneath the body.
Janet matched his movements and did the same from the opposing side.
And with two swings they launched the body into the hole, where it landed with a solid THUD.
Janet noticed a clip-on ID fell from the dead man's jacket onto a pile of dirt outside the makeshift grave.
She placed her foot on top of it, hoping the Senator didn't notice.
As he was pouring lime into the hole she quickly bent down and picked up the ID, sliding it into the pocket of her sweatpants.
"Janet, did you just pick something up?"
"Oh, no, Senator - I just dropped the flashlight for a second... got a case of the butterfingers, I guess."
"Okay, just checking", the Senator replied as he started to shovel the dirt back into the grave.
In that moment, Janet knew the ID in her pocket was her only chance to get out of this without ending up in a matching makeshift grave.
And that does it for tonight. Tomorrow and every night there'll be another chapter. We will start the new year with new FUEL DUMP!

FUEL DUMP, CHAPTER SIX (continued).
Nurse Abagail pulled her bombed out station wagon into the strip mall and parked directly in front of the karate studio.
She was still wearing her nurse's uniform, which always turned Derrick on for some reason.
To her the uniform just reminded her of work.
And work reminded her how disgusting the human body could be at its worst.
It had been years since she had to do 'nuts and butts' duty, but still - when you get down to it, people are really fucking disgusting.
Through the window she could see Derrick, sitting at his desk.
He was on the phone, arguing with someone so loudly that the conversation was bleeding through to the sidewalk.
Probably about money... it's always about money.
As she entered the studio, Derrick ended the conversation with a deafening "FUCK YOU!" before slamming the receiver onto the cradle.
"What's wrong, babe - money stuff again?"
Derrick smiled when he saw her walk towards him.
He really really really wanted to have sex with her right then.
Sometimes he had to play games in his head to stop thinking about sex, even for fifteen seconds.
"Yeah, I just talked to a liquidator about selling off some stuff to cover the rent, and guess how much he said this place was worth?"
"I dunno, how much?"
"He said that the ENTIRE value of this business was two hundred and eleven dollars - can you believe that?
I mean, these jigsaw floormats cost me five hundred dollars alone!"
He tried to look as righteously indignant before quietly suggesting, 'Hey, you wouldn't want to...?"
"No, not right now," Janet cut him off.
Derrick looked sincerely bummed out and could not hide it, no matter how hard he tried.
"You sure?"
"Yes, I'm sure," Abagail insisted.
"You're sure you're sure?"
"Look, Derrick - there's something brewing with one of my patients at the hospital, and I think there's a lot of money at stake."
Money was the only thing that Derrick liked as much as sex.
"What is it, babe?"
"Some old fossil on the third floor started blabbing to me about how he hid a lot of money somewhere."
"Did he say where he hid it?"
"No, but he's been trying to get in touch with his nephew - he's the only one who he trusts."
"So what's the play here?" Derrick asked.
A sinister smile snaked across Abagail's lips.
"You're gonna pose as his nephew, check the fossil out of the hospital, then we get him to tell us where the money is hidden."
"But what if he doesn't tell us?"
"He'll tell us."
And that does it for FUEL DUMP for tonight. Another chapter tomorrow!
And here comes another chapter of FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel. Written one sentence at a time.
FUEL DUMP CHAPTER SEVEN
Michael Richards looked at his watch again, wondering how thirty seconds could feel like two hours.
When was this guy gonna answer the door?
Then there was a creak, followed by a thin beam of light, as the front door opened just a crack.
Michael tilted the gun behind his leg, so whomever was on the other side of that door wouldn't see what he was holding.
"Who's there?" a young man asked from behind the door.
"Hey, Benny - it's me, Mike Richards!
Can I come in for a minute?"
After a second's hesitation, the door opened and Michael Richards made his way inside.
The house was a shithole, just like he remembered it.
And standing in the middle of the room was Benny Craig, sweatpants and doorag, still the same fake rap clown he was the day he met him.
Benny looked nervous, shifting his balance from foot to foot every few seconds.
"What's that behind your back, Kramer?"
That did it.
Stealing my money is one thing.
I mean, of course there's a risk in any investment.
But it really seemed like this - FOR GOD'S SAKE DON'T SAY IT - young businessman knew what he was talking about.
But now I'm out one hundred sixty grand and he doesn't seem one bit sorry.
But after all that to call me Kramer?
Un Fucking Acceptable.
"It's a goddamn gun, Benny."
And with that he pulled the shotgun from behind his leg and raised the barrel to Benny Craig's eye.
One wrong move and he would blow his brains all over this dump.
Another chapter tomorrow night. Merry Christmas! And once they're all up, the new chapters will arrive!
I fell asleep last night and didnt get to post a chapter of Fuel Dump, my Twitter novel. So I will do it RIGHT NOW. Get ready!
FUEL DUMP. CHAPTER SEVEN, PART TWO. 'An ill wind hast blown this way.' - W. Shakespeare
Where in blazes is my rice pudding?", the Colonel yelled at the orderly trying to serve him his lunch.
But it was too late - the damn kid turned on his heel and left the room.
"I know he hoyd me, damnit" the Colonel muttered to no one in particular.
The guy they dumped in the other bed barely even spoke English.
All he did was moan about how his head hurt and how he used to be a proud man back in his village.
The Colonel noticed some movement in the doorway from the corner of his eye and turned, hoping the damn kid had his pudding after all.
But it wasn't the orderly... or anyone that he recognized, for that matter.
It was some dumb looking muscle head with a walrus mustache, doing his best to hold a fake smile on his nervous face.
It looked like he was wearing some sort of karate getup under his bomber jacket.
"Can I help you with something, son?"
The guy stepped right into his first words like he had been rehearsing this moment all day.
"What are you talking about, Uncle Randy?
It's me - your nephew Kurt."
"You're not Kurt."
"Sure I am, Uncle Randy... and I'm getting you out of here today.
We're gonna take care of you at home - we've got a room set up for you and an on-call nurse and everything."
"Suh, I have no idea who in blazes you are or what you're up to but I am most certainly not leaving this hospital with you."
Then Nurse Abagail walked into the room - if anyone would straighten this out, it would be her.
"Nurse - this young charlatan is claiming to be nephew, but he is most certainly not -"
Nurse Abagail cut him off with an authority he had never seen from her.
"So this is the nephew that you've been trying to reach all week, eh, Colonel?
Well, I am certainly going to miss having you as a patient, but it appears that you're in very capable hands."
"But he's not my nephew.... what in blazes is going on heauh?"
"It's time for your shot, Colonel" she said while tapping her middle finger against the side of a syringe filled with something yellow.
Nurse Abagail sunk the needle into his arm and within seconds he could feel the shot taking effect.
And the last thing he saw before sleep hit was the shaved baboon with the karate getup smile like he was getting away with something.
That's it for FUEL DUMP today. Another chapter will come late tonight! When Im caught up the new stuff starts! Spread the word!!
And here it comes - more FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel written one sentence at a time. Read it, love it, RT it.
FUEL DUMP, Chapter Seven Part Three. 'How does it feel?' - B. Dylan.
Kurt Beaudreau sat in Kid Rock's self-described 'Gold Records Room', framed disc after framed disc covering every inch of every wall.
Kid Rock stood a few feet away in front of a shitty boombox, skipping through tracks on a CD-R.
"Yeah... this is the one.... my new stuff... this one is THE SHIT", he said as he turned proudly to meet Kurt's admiring gaze.
Kurt started fiddling with his digital recorder, getting ready to start the interview of his life.
The music, while completely awesome - some sort of Skynyrd/Blues Brothers/Run DMC hybrid - was throwing him off his rhythm.
Finally Kid Rock turned to Kurt, quite deliberately forcing his Confederate flag belt buckle in the young reporter's face.
"So, what the fuck does CIGAR AFICIONADO need to know about me, man?"
"Well... when you are picking a cigar, what role does robustness play in -"
Kurt didn't get the rest of the question out.
The explosion from outside was so deafening it made the windows shatter and walls shake, sending most of the gold records to the floor.
It was weird - the way Kid Rock was standing, seeing the flames and smoke from the window behind him, it was like one of his videos.
But this was no video; Kid Rock was laying on the ground in front of him, groaning and bleeding, his pork pie hat singed and bloodied.
With the room on fire, the song blasting from the boombox - the chorus mentioned 'partying your dick off' - sounded cheap and pathetic.
And within seconds it was drowned out by the whirring blades of a helicopter hovering outside the window of the second floor room.
Kurt saw the turrets attached to the base of the cockpit swivel in his direction and knew he had one second - two tops - to make a move.
He grabbed Kid Rock by his legs - sending him to the floor with a THUD - and dragged him into the hallway.
The copter's machine guns tore up every inch of the room in its path a moment later.
And that does it for FUEL DUMP tonight. It's only going to get MORE EXCITING and INSANE. So please TELL ALL YOUR FRIENDS.
And now another installment of FUEL DUMP. We are catching up on the old chapters at our new home, then the new chapters start!
FUEL DUMP Chapter Seven, Part Four. "I aint no goddamn son of a bitch; You better think about it, baby." - G. Danzig.
Joe Leiberman looked into the camera and talked directly to the people of Connecticut, like he had done so many times before.
"Raccoons are not the cuddly creatures you see in cartoons and on cereal boxes.
They carry diseases that can infect you and your family.
So if you see a raccoon on your property, do not approach it, and by all means do not fet - I mean PET.... can we start over?"
The director - a young go-getter named Jordan Walninger - sighed and lifelessly told the senator, 'sure - let's take it from the top.'
Lieberman rubbed his finger across his teeth and prepared for another take.
But before he could start, his cellphone played a familiar tune: "Josie's on a vacation far away...".
Lieberman looked at the number on the phone and immediately looked pained.
He stepped away from the set and answered the phone with a quiet anger, spitting out a curt "This is not a good time, Barry".
But Barry - who sounded like he was talking while driving that dumb sportscar of his - wasn't having any of the senator's indignity.
"I heard that you think a co-worker of mine had something that you thought belonged to you."
"It DID belong to me, you f-ing fat tub of goo!
And I'm not going to let you spin it in whatever direction you think will justify your idiotic worldview, Barry!"
A pause on the phone long enough to make Lieberman think the call was dropped until Barry replied, "Ooooh, so now I'm an idiot, huh?
I wasn't such an idiot when you needed me to take care of that other thing two years ago, huh?
Well, my co-worker hasn't turned up in eight days now, Joey Baby.
And if I don't hear from him soon, you're the first one I'm gonna talk to about where he might be".
Lieberman tried to cut in, but Barry had hung up already.
Jordan Walninger stepped up to Lieberman and aggressively said, "We don't have all day on this one, Joe."
That was all it took.
Lieberman started slapping and punching Walninger again and again, letting out every ounce of frustration on the hapless director.
"WHO THE FUCK SAID YOU COULD CALL ME JOE?!!" he screamed as he unearthed a surprisingly brutal beatdown on Walninger.
But with every slap and kick, one thing flashed through Lieberman's mind: the body he buried and the woman who knew about it.
She was a loose end, sure - but she might be a little too loose for comfort.
And that does it for tonight! A quickie but a goodie! There's better stuff yet to come! Tell your friends and foes alike about FUEL DUMP!
And here comes another chapter of Fuel Dump, my Twitter novel. Get on board, friends! And tell your buddies about this! Thanks!
FUEL DUMP CHAPTER SEVEN PART FIVE - "When my situation ain't improving, I'm trying to murder everything moving" - Jay Z
The year was 1977 and Dennis Wilson was as wasted as he had ever been - man, did Hawaii have the best heroin or what?
He stood on the balcony of his hotel in Kona, the wind kissing his face with enough force to remind him he was still completely high.
Then he realized - shit, that deal Morton had been working on was supposed to go down in an hour.
He called downstairs and, in his best 'straight' voice, asked the girl at the front desk to have his car sent around.
A half hour later and Dennis is hanging out the limo window, begging the same winds that felt so good on the balcony to wake him up.
The limo finally pulled up to the shitty makeshift airport, and there was Morton standing along his car, holding the briefcase.
Dennis got out and staggered over to Morton, the drink in his hand rattling with every uneasy step.
"Are you drunk, Dennis?" Morton exclaimed, with real worry in his voice.
"Aaaaaah, fuck it Morton; this deal is gonna make us a ton of fucking money, man, and I don't wanna hear your whining right now!"
And before they could straighten out their differences, the hum of a biplane heading toward the runway made them both weirdly silent.
Two men dressed like mobsters from a cheap movie stepped from the plane.
"So, you are the Dennis Wilson, yes?", one asked in a shaky Spanish accent, "the Beach Boy?"
Dennis knew right then he had these dudes in the palm of his hand.
"The one and the same," he replied with the same swagger that kept him neck deep in snizz for nearly two decades.
"It is an honor to make this deal with you, Mister Beach Boy," the man said as the other man handed him a poster tube.
"I am sure you will find the poppy fields to your liking, Beach Boy," he continued, with a noticeable diminishing of respect this time.
He set the poster tube on the roof of the limo, then gestured to Morton, asking 'Now may I see the four million dollars please?"
Morton snapped open the briefcase and his wish was granted - four million dollars laid out in neat rows before him.
Dennis Wilson unrolled the map in the poster tube, focusing on the small red circle over a town called Jalpan.
"Fuck the Beach Boys and that bald asshole Mike Love; when this thing pans out, I'm gonna be richer than Brian," he thought to himself.
AND THAT concludes FUEL DUMP for tonight. The will ALL make sense. This is called BACKSTORY and it's apparently NECESSARY to tell a story.
Another chapter tomorrow. Then when we're caught up the new stuff arrives!
And here comes another installment of FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel. Reposting the old chapters one a day. The new stuff follows the old!
FUEL DUMP, Chapter Eight, Part One. "Let it be" - The Beatles
Benny felt the sweat beading off his forehead and assumed it was running onto the barrel of the gun pressed to his temple.
All he could think was, 'Am I really going to die by the hand of Michael Richards?'
He didn't even like that show much, really - he was more of a FRIENDS man when it came down to it.
"You really let me down, Benny.
You know how long it took me to make 160 grand?
A long, long time, Benny."
Michael Richards held the gun against Benny's face and wondering if and when he would pull the trigger.
He didn't want to do it, of course - all this dipshit did was take him for a ride on an investment that was a total longshot.
Seriously, what made him think this kid knew anything about opening a chain of Michael Richards-endorsed slot car racing tracks?
And he could make 160 grand in an afternoon during the Good Old Days - hardly a 'long long time.'
So why am I standing here with a gun pressed to this dumb kid's face?
I'm rich, I'm good looking, I'm primed to pull off the biggest comeback in showbiz history... and I'm gonna throw all that away?
And with that thought Michael pulled the gun back and lowered the barrel to the floor.
A second later he felt something - a bat, maybe? - land across his shoulder blades with a dull thump.
From the side of his eye he saw a short guy - that wasn't Mickey, was it?! - cocking back a wooden bat, preparing for another swing.
Michael jumped out of the way but lost the grip on his gun in the process.
Benny had the shotgun up and aimed at that famous head of hair within seconds.
And Michael Richards went from wondering whether he would take a life to whether he was ready to die.
But he wasn't gonna beg this - this - this - youth for his life; he'd rather take his chances with the window next to the front door.
And with a crash he jumped through it, rolling onto the porch, spinning down the steps, across the yard to his Dodge Durango.
He was speeding down Formosa in seconds, sheets of perspiration pouring down his face, oblivious to the sedan tailing his every move.
And that concludes tonight's FUEL DUMP. More tomorrow! RT! Tell your friends! Read it at your church! Spread the word!
And here is a FUEL DUMP recap, keeping you all up to speed with whats going on!
FUEL DUMP RECAP. When we last checked in, MICHAEL RICHARDS was running for his life after an armed confrontation turned south.
And JOE LIEBERMAN was having a meltdown, worrying about the body he buried and whether his assistant JANET MANZ would spill the beans.
Cigar Aficionado reporter KURT BEAUDREAU and KID ROCK were being fired at by a machine gun on Kid Rock's Michigan compound.
Martial arts instructor DERRICK and his lady NURSE ABAGAIL kidnapped THE COLONEL to find out about some hidden secrets.
And back in 1977, DENNIS WILSON was about to pull off a massive drug deal with shady partner MORTON.
And here comes another installment of Fuel Dump, my Twitter novel. An old chapter a day, then the new stuff arrives!
FUEL DUMP, CHAPTER EIGHT PART TWO - "I gotta feeling!"; The Beatles, 1970.
Joe Lieberman sat in his office, rocking back and forth in his Aeron chair, his leg shaking a mile a minute.
He knew that the situation with Janet Manz was one step away from turning into a Major Fucking Problem, and he had to take action.
But what could he do?
Cutting her in on the deal that drove him to murder was a pipe dream at best - who knew if and when he'd actually see any money?
But he really didn't want to kill her.
Killing that last guy was such a fluke in retrospect.
He had heard about how taking your first life often awoke a 'blood lust' inside some people, driving them to kill again and again.
But all Lieberman felt was a fair amount of nausea and a ton of guilt.
But if there was no money and he couldn't bring himself to take another life, how on earth could he get Janet Manz out of the picture?
On the other side of Lieberman's office door, Janet Manz was also wondering how she would remove herself from this mess.
Over the last week, she had seen a side of the Senator that made her very very scared.
He was cagey and wired, and anytime she looked him in the eye he was unable to hold her gaze.
She had always enjoyed locking eyes with Lieberman while explaining a travel deduction, his cold slate pupils tracking every word.
But now she felt he was capable of anything to tie up the mess he had made.
Janet knew he had killed at least once before, so what would prevent him from doing it again?
She clicked away at her computer keyboard, searching the name on the ID tag at the burial site.
Ferd McAllister, Jr.
Google eventually found him on Facebook... weirdly enough, Janet realized she had already friended him (though she friended EVERYBODY).
For the last few months she had regretted adding anybody who requested friendship - she felt it cheapened her Facebook account.
With two thousand-plus friends, she couldn't keep track of the people she actually knew.
And the notion of finding a decent guy in this sea of fake friends?
Impossible.
Because otherwise she wouldn't have figured out who Ferd McAllister, Jr. is and why Senator Joe Lieberman was driven to murder him.
Janet knew that knowing who Ferd was might be the only thing that could keep her alive at this point.
And she was right.
Because in his office Senator Joe Lieberman was calling an old acquaintance from his cell phone.
"Hello, Yancy?
It's Senator Joe - there's a little... problem that I would like you to take care of for me."
On the other end of the line Lieberman heard a gun click and winced, but knew that it must be done.
Another chapter tomorrow! RT this! Tell your friends! Hype it to the ends of the twitterverse and beyond! I need the help! Thanks!
And now another chapter of FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel. Posting the old chapters here, then when we're caught up, the new stuff starts!
FUEL DUMP, CHAPTER NINE - "EVERYBODY HURTS... SOMETIMES". (Trad., arr. Berry/Buck/Mills/Stipe)
The Colonel awoke in the backseat of the kind of car that those loud kids used to drive up and down his street back in the seventies.
And of course the driver was that baboon in the karate getup pretending to be his nephew Kurt.
He must've signed me out of the hospital... but where is he taking me and what in blazes could he possibily want?
'I've faced down death so many times before,' The Colonel thought to himself as he tried in vain to recognize the street rolling past.
'I got enough horse sense to know my number's gotta come up one of these days.
But I'll be doggone if I'm gonna let this karate ape be the one who says when it's all over.'
The Colonel decided he would pretend to be asleep - though who could sleep thru that music? - and wait for a plan to reveal itself.
Up front, Derrick drove, drumming on the steering wheel in an attempt to keep up with the double time finale of 'Paradise City'.
He sucked on the belt of his gi like a seven year old who hates the karate lessons his mom signed him up for.
Two things were on his mind - getting the old man out of the car and into the cellar, and whether the new issue of SWANK was out yet.
That last issue was the hottest one in years, but he had a feeling that the new issue might somehow top it.
But it was all a moot point if he didn't get the bag of bones on his backseat into the cellar, where the interrogation could begin.
The old man had been prattling on about needing to tell his nephew exactly where he had hidden a stash of money.
They would get the details out of him one way or another; it was up to the old man how - holy shit, I bet that 7-11 has the new SWANK.
Derrick knew he shouldn't stop, but a quick glance told him the old man was still knocked out - it would take two minutes, tops.
If they had the new SWANK he'd buy it; if not maybe he'd grab the new GENT.
Either way he'd be back on the road in a matter of seconds... he'd even leave the car running just to trim a few seconds off his time.
Derrick pulled into a spot with a screech and ran inside, the motor idling quietly, the unused keys slowly swinging back and forth.
The Colonel leaned up with a grunt, realizing that his plan had arrived much sooner than he thought it would.
And that does it for tonight. Another chapter tomorrow. We're almost caught up! Tell your friends! RT! Spread the word! Happy New Year!
More FUEL DUMP, my Twitter novel coming NOW! We finish posting the old chapters then the NEW ONES WILL START!
FUEL DUMP CHAPTER NINE, PART TWO. Another Trip Into The Past.
"Four days from now and it'll be 1984... unbelievable, right?"
"And why would that be unbelievable?" said Randall Beaudreau as he slid into the high backed red leather booth, a drink in each hand.
The man across from him answered with a muffled snort, "because of the book 1984."
But books didn't mean a damn thing to Colonel Randall C. Beaudreau, who in all of his 48 years never read more than an Archie comic.
"So what is this heah business deal you wanted to talk to me about, Mistuh..."
"Crane - Morton Crane", replied the sweaty man as he swooped up the drink Beaudreau set in front of him.
He took a huge sip before trying to make the spiel he had been rehearsing for the last twelve hours sound half-remembered.
"A friend of a friend tells me that you are someone who has a knack for getting things from one place to another.
A large amount of money fell into my lap due to the death of my business partner yesterday."
We had a good chunk of land down in Mexico, and over the last couple years business has been very very good."
The Colonel let this buffoon ramble on, answering questions that he never asked.
"What kind of business you runnin' down there in Mehico, Morton?"
The Colonel knew Morton was in the drug trade when he first saw him strutting around in that cheap suit, but he decided to play dumb.
"Let's just say I make my living by bringing joy to the world," Morton answered with a smile.
"I'm sorry about the death of your partnuh, Mister Crane - it's always sad when those close to us pass away."
Morton dismissed the notion with a wave, adding, "No big deal - the dickhead was high - big shocker - and drowned yesterday.
But I guess that means since we're not exactly a public corporation here, I get his half of the business.
What I'd like to do is take the money," - he whispered this next part - "nine million bucks" - he talked loudly again - "and parlay it."
Five minutes later they were in the parking lot of the Blue Moon Pub, sitting in the front seat of Morton's Cadillac.
"Now tell me... what exactly would I be doin' with this money again?"
Morton snorted again before answering, "it's simple - you get the money into Romania.
You'll buy as many guns as you can get for the nine mil.
Then you bring them back here however the hell you do that - and you have done that before, right?"
This dumbass, telling me the plan was simple; if it's so damn simple, you do it.
Then he's got the nerve to question whether I've done this before?
I've been making things appear and disappear all over the world since this kid was a stain in his daddy's under britches.
But The Colonel bit his tongue and said, "Sure thing, Morton... when do you want this to go down?"
"Right now, if you're ready - I got the money packed away in two suitcases in my trunk."
He has the money with him NOW?!... Was this the dumbest dumbass who ever walked God's glorious earth?!
By now The Colonel was entertaining walking away from this straight up - this kid was just too damn dumb to not mess this up somehow.
But his decision making process changed when he heard a CLICK and felt the cold steel of a pistol pressed against his cheek.
"And I can trust you, can't I, boy?"
That was the final straw, calling me boy, The Colonel thought.
With one quick turn he elbowed Morton in the throat, sending his arms flailing forward.
The gun slipped from his hand and hit the back seat with a bounce before going off with a BANG.
The Colonel didn't feel any pain, so he knew he hadn't been shot... but Morton was a different story.
The dumbass clutched the back of his neck and started groaning and wheezing like a stuck pig.
The Colonel reached into the back seat and picked up the gun before hopping out of the car.
And just like he had expected, the backup had arrived: two goons stepping from the shadows, reaching into their jackets.
The Colonel aimed the pistol and without hesitation shot both men - one in the kneecap, the other in the dead center of his chest.
He looked into the car and saw Morton now laying across the front seat, moaning to nobody in particular.
He reached in and grabbed the keys from the ignition, careful to avoid the streaks of blood smeared on the steering column.
The Colonel popped the trunk open and yeah, there were two suitcases back there, just like the dumbass had said.
He pulled them from the trunk with a grunt and walked across the parking lot to his own car.
By the time a cop finally discovered one of the goons writhing on the asphalt - the other was long dead - The Colonel was miles away.
And that does it for FUEL DUMP tonight! Another few old chapters to go then the NEW STUFF BEGINS! And tell EVERYONE about it! RT this!!

I am posting the old chapters. Then the new stuff will start. You can catch up by clicking on my Favorites and reading from the bottom up.
FUEL DUMP CHAPTER NINE, PART THREE. "All the crack heads, the critics, the cynics, and all my heroes at the Methadone Clinic" - Kid Rock
Kurt Beaudreau carried a whining Kid Rock past the small fires and shattered glass scattered through his bullet-ridden mansion.
The rocker kept moaning about his ankle, which got twisted in the wake of the helicopter's machine gun fire.
Kurt finally got his hero into a room at the end of a long hallway at the opposite end of the mansion.
"This is one of my sex rooms", Kid Rock proclaimed proudly as Kurt dropped him onto an oversized bed.
Kurt noticed that the THUT THUT THUT of the helicopter blades had stopped, so he peeked through the blinds to the compound outside.
He realized the chopper had landed, and a few guys holding guns were having a conversation outside the cockpit.
Kid Rock rolled backwards on the bed, staring at the ceiling.
He had no idea why this was happening to him - who would want to kill him?
He started to whimper silently, knowing his plan to die while having sex was now a stark impossibility.
His thoughts then drifted to a stripper at the Ice Cream Castle in Houston... her name was Charise, and she was PERFECT.
Meanwhile, Kurt couldnt stop thinking about his uncle and how he would handle this situation.
He wouldn't lay down and let these goons roll over them without a fight.... he'd do whatever it took to get out of this mess.
"We need to find a place to hide, Kid - somewhere they can't find us."
"Why bother, man", Kid Rock stammered between his tears, "they're gonna find us and kill us.
Can't you hear it - they're already in the house looking for us!"
He was right; the gunmen could be heard downstairs talking to each other, speaking broken English with Russian (?) accents.
THIS IS NOT FAIR AND I DONT WANT TO DIE", Kid Rock moaned to himself over and over.
Kurt sat next to Kid on the bed and tried to calm him down.
"I dont know who these guys are and why they're trying to kill you, but we're in this together and we'll get out of it together."
Just then Kurt heard one of the gunmen say something that made his heart sink into the pit of his stomach.
They said his name.
The next sound was a CLICK, but it came from within the room.
Kid Rock had a revolver cocked at Kurt's head.
And with one of his classic greasy smiles, he said, "They don't want me, Kurt.... they want YOU."
And that's enough of FUEL DUMP for tonight. Thanks! I promise you I will right the ship. I was busy. But now I am slightly less busy.
And here's a little more FUEL DUMP. This thing WILL get back on track. Spot me some goodwill and trust.
FUEL DUMP Chapter Nine, Part Three. "Picnic in cemetery, cocaine and Shasta... cherry." - Beat Happening.
The lights of Los Angeles were a multicolored blur from where Michael Richards was sitting.
His Dodge Durango whipped down Santa Monica Boulevard, disregarding traffic lights and stop signs.
He felt justified in driving like this; two minutes ago he almost got his head cracked open by a baseball bat.
And Richards was CERTAIN that someone was tailing him.
And he wasn't wrong: someone WAS tailing him, although it wasn't Benny or anyone from the house.
A black sedan tried to stick with the Durango as it weaved back and forth, disregarding anything or anyone in its path.
"Goddamnit, he's making it hard to stay with him," the driver said to the man sitting next to him in the passenger seat.
"Just keep your eyes locked on that bumper sticker on his back window," the co-pilot replied.
The driver zeroed in on the 'HEY JERRY!' bumper sticker affixed to the Durango and kept his hands locked on the steering wheel.
Inside the Durango, Michael Richards laced through traffic, his cell phone pressed to the side of his head.
The number he dialed went straight to voicemail: "This is Ferd, sorry I'm not there but leave a message and I'll get back to you!"
"Come on, Ferd, where are you," Richards moaned as he threw the cell phone onto the dashboard.
Ferd would know what to do - he could always figure out how to get out of any mess, no matter how big or sticky.
But he hadn't been able to get in touch with the man he called 'Big F' for the last week now.
What would 'The Big F' do at a time like this?
How would he get out of this mess?
The light at the intersection of Santa Monica and Bedford turned red, and the Durango actually stopped.
The co-pilot in the sedan reached into the glove compartment and pulled out a handgun, cocking it for action before opening his door.
Then without warning, the Durango skidded backwards, exploding into the car behind it.
Both sets of airbags deployed and just like that Michael Richards had eluded his captors.
An hour later he was sitting on a red eye flight to LaGuardia Airport.
It wasn't like Ferd to not answer his cellphone for a week, so Richards would grab a rental car and drive to Connecticut in the morning.
Find out what the deal was himself.
Ferd meant more to him than anyone else at this point - he was his advisor, his guru, his North Star through all the turbulent times.
So he owed it to the man to check things out and see what's what.
Besides, after all this insanity it would be nice to drive around Connecticut - give him a chance to do some real thinking for once.
The man across the aisle finally caught Richards' eye and reached out a friendly hand.
"Oh man, I am such a big fan of yours, Mister Richards."
"Why thank you", the dose of fan worship coating his ego like the frosting on the pre-flight Cinnabon he knocked back an hour ago.
"Could I get you to sign something for me," the man inquired, passing over a small cocktail napkin and a pen.
Richards usually didnt sign on airplanes, but this was different... "Sure thing - what's your name?"
"It's Yancy", the man replied with a smile.
Almost caught up. Then we roll forward into the new stuff. I PROMISE.
And now I drop a little FUEL DUMP on you. It's my Twitter novel, being written one sentence at a time.
I am posting the previous chapters on its new home at @FuelDumpNovel. Then the new stuff begins! Trust me! I will see this through!
FUEL DUMP CHAPTER NINE, PART THREE "bwaaaap booo bwaaaa.... boooo bwaaaa booooop!" Miles Davis "Pharaoh's Dance"
Kid Rock kept pressing the gun tighter against the head of Kurt Beaudreau as the sound of the intruders got closer.
He knew it was a straight up chickenshit move to sell this dumb kid out like this, but what other option did he have?
Besides, it wasn't the first time he chumped out for a little personal gain.
He recalled the time he made Uncle Kracker take the fall for burning down that rec center back in Clawson.
Or that incident where he knocked his Hummer into that kid driving a moped in Glendale.
The kid went sailing into a trench off the highway, but he never stopped to make sure he was okay.
But hey, its a hard fucking life, right?
You're either the one getting punched, or you're the one doing the punching.
So in the cosmic scheme of things, selling out this reporter kid to some Russian hoods wouldn't add up to a hill of beans.
Kid Rock heard the reporter draw in a breath as if to say something.
"Kid...... Robert..... why are you doing this to me?"
And for the first time in ages - probably since that doctor told him he had 'flagrant Chlamydia' - Kid Rock was rendered speechless.
The answer didn't matter, because the doorknob turned and four Russian goons stepped in with their semiautomatic weapons drawn.
They started shouting at each other in what might actually not be Russian, pointing over at Kurt with the tips of their weapons.
One goon made it clear that he was in charge and gestured for the other three to round up their prisoners and lead them outside.
If there was one thing that Kurt Beaudreau learned from his uncle, it was never to get inside a vehicle with your captors.
Once you were inside a moving vehicle, all bets were off - they had the upper hand.
You were always better off putting up a fight and taking your chances.
One of the goons gestured for Kid Rock to lower his gun, but the rocker had other ideas.
"I captured this guy for you, comrades.... let me go."
He then broke out his trademark greasy smile - the one that said 'You know I'm the shit, dude'.
The Russian (?) smiled back, then spun his gun around, cracking Kid Rock in the jaw with its butt.
The American Bad Ass lifelessly slid off the bed and fell to the floor in a stupid heap.
Kurt rose slowly from the bed, his arms raised above his head in the universal sign of surrender.
As they marched him down the hallway, the prisoner looked for an opportunity to make a move - anything.
But there was nothing.
Once they made it out the front door, it was a clear path to the helicopter; who knew what would happen after that?
So Kurt decided he would run as fast as he could away from them and hope they didn't shoot him.
Of course it was a horrible plan!
And as he broke away from the goons in a spastic sprint, he wondered if he might've been better off taking his chances in the copter.
It certainly caught the goons by surprise.
I mean, who would actually run away from four dudes holding machine guns?
Although the sexy artwork scattered throughout Kid Rock's mansion provided a pretty solid distraction.
After all, what would YOU rather look at - the back of some dumb American's head or a painting of a rock star having sex with a guitar?
So yeah, the prisoner had gotten the drop on them.
But even though he had ducked into a side room, they had machine guns - say he somehow got his own gun, it was still four against one.
So when the bottle of vodka with a flaming rag sticking from the top shattered onto the carpet beneath their feet, they WERE surprised.
One of them even raised an eyebrow in odd admiration til fire raced across his pant leg, flames leaping upward onto the spattered vodka.
As the Russians (?) were busy putting themselves out, Kurt ran down the hall and out the front door.
He mounted the dirtbike parked in the driveway and drove off the compound, spitting a trail of gravel and dust in his wake.
Kurt Beaudreau then realized he had been set up, and he planned to pay a visit to the CIGAR AFICIONADO offices to find out why.
And now we are CAUGHT UP with FUEL DUMP. The old chapters are UP. And the NEW STUFF starts THIS WEEK. TELL EVERYBODY! RT! SPREAD THE WORD!
FUEL DUMP. Chapter Ten. The Reckoning.
Chaz Paulinuck had struggled with writer's block before, but this time it seemed different.
You'd think it was to be expected of someone with five best sellers to his name - at some point the well might run a little dry.
But man, it was never THIS bad.
Chuck knew he dodged a bullet with his last novel VOMITORIUM. He knew that it was a reheated version of a short story he wrote in college.
The story ended up in THE CHAZ PAULINUCK READER, but nobody seemed to notice the similarities that absolutely screamed out at him.
How could his fans not notice that both stories were about a militia so off the grid that they use barf as currency?
That's probably because for the most part his fans were a sea of mouthbreathers who mistook shock for innovation.
Sometimes at book readings he fantasized about machine gunning everybody sitting in front of him with their dumb jaws agape.
It was a satisfying fantasy until he realized he had already used it in TWERP, a novella about a man who eats pornography for money.
With a pained sigh, Chaz realized that while his fans might not catch on for another two years, he was cooked. Nothing left in the tank.
Unless he did something about it.
No more hiding cheap gimmicks or stunts. He needed to get up and do something. He needed to FEEL something for once.
The next book had to be something that came from his heart, not from his head.
It would be about living and dying. But not some imagined version of it. This book would capture what it's like to actually fight to live.
Chaz scrolled through his address book, looking for the number of a guy he met at a signing in Portland.
When he found the number - the guy's name was Jock and he had scrawled 'real sicko' next to his name, he grabbed his phone and dialed.
Jock answered after two rings with a creepy half-stoned 'hellooooo?'
"Jock, it's Chaz Paulinuck. We met at a signing a couple years ago."
"Yeah, yeah... what's up, man? I gotta tell you - VOMITORIUM is probably the best book I've ever read. It's an f-ing classic."
Chaz held his tongue and pushed ahead. "You said you knew some sick dudes back in Bakersfield, right?"
"Yeah, man. These dudes will do anything for a buck. And I mean anything."
Chaz hesitated before dropping the Big Question in front of a guy he barely knew. But he pushed on. "Would any of them... kill someone?"
"You kidding me? These guys'll slice someone's neck and not think twice about it. Why? You looking to have someone offed?"
"Yeah, I am."
"Any chance you'll tell me who it is?"
"Sure. It's me."
Five minutes later Chaz was bouncing around the room. He never felt so alive. For better or worse, this was happening.
He wasn't wrong - things WERE happening. Jock stood at a payphone outside a Quiznos, tapping his fingers, the receiver folded into his jaw.
No answer. So he left a message. "Hey, Yancy. It's Jock. I got a job for you. The usual business. But this one is a doozy."
